etymology.description: 人 (“person”) + two marks encompassing, indicating “in between”; folk etymology interprets the two marks as armor parts.
etymology.interpretation: Shows a person situated between two boundaries, yielding the core sense of being in the middle or between. By extension it developed uses like introduce (to place someone between parties) and was later associated with armor/shell through folk or literary reinterpretation.

examples.chinese: 这条河介于两座城市之间(這條河介於兩座城市之間)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tiáo hé jièyú liǎng zuò chéngshì zhī jiān.
examples.english: This river lies between two cities.

examples.chinese: 老师介绍了新同学(老師介紹了新同學)。
examples.english: The teacher introduced the new student.

examples.chinese: 贝类的介壳很坚硬(貝類的介殼很堅硬)。
examples.english: The shells of mollusks are very hard.
